discourse_list.title: Decentralized Voter Committees: startup phase - Wednesdays 5pm CEST. All MKR holders welcome

content.content: After the success of last weeks Tuesday Voter Committee where almost 100 people showed up, I will be repeating the calls every week at Tuesday 5pm CEST.  Weekly Call: Wednesdays 5pm CEST 2022-06-01T15:00:00Z  Zoom Link   Objective The goal of these general voter committees will be to try to agree on an overall top down structure of how to categorize the activities and strategic initiatives of MakerDAOs decentralized workforce, in order to create more specialized voter committees that cover each category.  image2452×1286 341 KB   image2516×1280 285 KB  For this upcoming call, tomorrow tuesday at 5pm CEST, I have asked Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling to provide a short overview of the different initiatives that exist within the core units now. The goal will be to try to find categories that already have enough interest for MKR holders to join if we begin arranging voter committees for them. So far there has been interest in an RWA voter committee. Call Join Link: Launch Meeting - Zoom

Here’s the link, open now    Zoom Video   Join our Cloud HD Video Meeting Zoom is the leader in modern enterprise video communications, with an easy, reliable cloud platform for video and audio conferencing, chat, and webinars across mobile, desktop, and room systems. Zoom Rooms is the original software-based conference...

Good talk today and a super in-depth presentation by @wouter. Hopefully All in the community will get to see the replay of such. One thing I wanted to ask with regards to Voter Committee’s, Allan Pedersen wrote a compelling piece on the work that goes into these Committees, and personally what resonated with me is the ability for Committee’s to review a deal by meeting with the management of the proposed asset type and at times going out to visually see the proposed asset. Now the latter only pertains to RWAs and more than likely the MakerDAO Voter Committees will not be traveling to inspect a construction site, or meet with a protocol that the Growth team is dealing with in another continent (as examples). So, how do you visualize Voter Committee’s trusting that Core Units have done the due diligence, placed their “boots on the ground”, etc., and are recommending a strategic Initiative that benefits MKR token owners and helps Voter Committee’s evaluate protocol features, RWAs, budgets, etc.? And zooming out, should Maker Committee membership be staggered in order to bring on new members with fresh ideas?

Thanks everyone for the useful meeting yesterday. This is the presentation I presented on the call:  docs.google.com    20220524 - Voting Committee Initiatives Update Voting Committee Initiatives Update 24 May 2022 Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling Core Unit        How does due diligence fit into this?     flipflopflapdelegate:  So, how do you visualize Voter Committee’s trusting that Core Units have done the due diligence, placed their “boots on the ground”, etc., and are recommending a strategic Initiative that benefits MKR token owners and helps Voter Committee’s evaluate protocol features, RWAs, budgets, etc.?   In my opinion, this is all about the Auditor function that the DAO is currently missing. As you point out, it is a lot of work to review the deliverables and review various aspects of the DAO’s operations: financial, secops, software quality assurance, legal due diligence, people best practices, etc. I’ve compared this with a specialized PC Review Magazine in the past, in the case of software quality assurance: when core unit releases new software, a group would be reviewing that and assigning a rating based on evaluation criteria that they develop. The consumers of these reviews are delegates, MKR holders (esp. the ones on the voter committees), and any other stakeholder who has an interest in MakerDAO delivering according to its best potential. Access to an auditor infrastructure as described would empower MKR holders to get better answers to the questions they have, delivered by sources with better incentive alignment than just the default “trust us, we’re professionals” reply from the executing core units themselves.  Previous work on this This was the point of the planned Transparency and Quality Control track of the new season of the SES Incubation Program. Later, the decision was made to postpone the acceleration of the program:  image1316×743 215 KB   image1315×738 212 KB  Source:   accounts.google.com   Google Slides - create and edit presentations online, for free. Create a new presentation and edit with others at the same time. Get stuff done with or without an internet connection. Use Slides to edit PowerPoint files. Free from Google.       MakerDAO today is a car without seatbelts As long as MakerDAO doesn’t have an auditor function, it is, in my opinion, incomplete and essentially broken. It’s operating but not with all the necessary safety checks in place. Like a car without safety belts and airbags. As long as this is the case, we shouldn’t be surprised when accidents happen or the DAO is operating sub-optimally. Cutting costs as retribution in such cases may be a counter-productive measure making the situation worse instead of better.  The first oversight Core Unit For structured finance (RWA collateral and similar real-world legal-integrated projects), luckily, there is the opportunity to vote for the first auditor core unit today, even if it may not cover all aspects of what you mentioned:     MIP39c2-SP33: Adding Lending Oversight Core Unit (LOVE-001) RFC   MIP39c2-SP33: Adding Lending Oversight Core Unit (LOVE-001)  Preamble MIP39c2-SP#: 33 Author(s): @luca_pro Contributors: @wouter, @Juan, @Retro Tags: core-unit, cu-love-001, mandate Status: RFC Date Proposed: 2022-05-11 Date Ratified: <yyyy-mm-dd> Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip39c2-sp33-adding-lending-oversight-core-unit-love-001/15098   Sentence Summary MIP39c2-SP33 adds the Lending Oversight (LOVE-001) Core Unit.   Paragraph Summary LOVE-001 intends to support the DAO in its evol…     I know that @luca_pro has a set of evaluation criteria in the works to review the performance of the RWF core units, although it may take a bit longer before that’s finished.  Other examples   Immunefi Security CU is clearly contributing to smart contract security and operational security checks with their roadmap. They collaborate with other in the Security cross-core unit initiative that was mentioned in the meeting and in the slides.   SES is conducting monthly budget statement audits of core units that we’re advising and who opted in to this. GovAlpha is running the same check on the SES budget. Important limitation of these is that the audits are focused on transparency and reporting QA, they are not meant to judge whether a core unit is spending their budget efficiently or wisely.   Smart contract audits are arranged through a coordination group that uses pre-purchased auditing credits from ChainSecurity for the most relevant projects we have in the pipeline.

flipflopflapdelegate:  So, how do you visualize Voter Committee’s trusting that Core Units have done the due diligence, placed their “boots on the ground”, etc., and are recommending a strategic Initiative that benefits MKR token owners and helps Voter Committee’s evaluate protocol features, RWAs, budgets, etc.?   Indulge a contrarian view for a second: Why do we uncritically assume that the solution to excessive bureaucracy to vote and cognitive overload is to add even more layers of informal governance between token holders and Core Units? The above sounds like the job of a delegate, that already exists.

The problem is that delegates have neither the time nor the expertise to do specialized reviews. I think they are already experiencing this today. So I don’t believe that will work in the long run. What can work in the short term is for like-minded delegates to team up and distribute these tasks among the group. Especially with delegates with different professional backgrounds. The audit function may not need big or multiple dedicated teams anytime soon. But it is an expected future need.

wouter:  The problem is that delegates have neither the time nor the expertise to do specialized reviews. I think they are already experiencing this today. So I don’t believe that will work in the long run.   Unless we compensate delegates appropriately for their time and expect enough time and attention in return. Others have mentioned this elsewhere I think. Regardless, I agree strongly with your view regarding the need for a separate audit function. Also agree it doesn’t need to be large, maybe 1-2 resources from an external company employed 50-100% as a separate Core Unit. It’s probably for the best that you postponed the Transparency track. Incubating within SES or an existing Core Unit would be a strategic mistake in my view, and would entangle the audit function hopelessly. But we could encourage auditors to apply through the MIP39 process and transfer all the auditing functions to them if approved.

It’s a hypothetical because it’s very unlikely the incubation program will return in its present form for the auditor track. There is one thing I want to clarify, however, because I’ve noticed misconceptions about it in the past:   SES holds no control whatsoever over core units once they are graduated.   While, in practice, we continue to be the budget statement reviewer of the graduated core units and some others we advised, this is entirely voluntary.   Core units that are reviewed by us are at any point free to stop the collaboration by submitting a new MIP40 with SES removed as auditor.   It is not our intention to keep the auditing function within SES. It’s only in our mandate if it’s temporary. We plan to spin this off into its own thing and if anyone wants to help us with this, you’re free to contact @juan or myself.   It might be a nice start to offer an alternative to core units who prefer not to work with SES. I asked @Aes ages ago whether SF would be willing to share this burden in the future. Back then he said he’d consider it, but as I said, it’s a while ago so I understand plans may have changed.   The budget statement review acts more like an accountant working with a client: in support of the core unit, helping them to follow best practices. But at the same time be a check that everything looks in order.

Maker needs more delgates with deep subject matter expertise.  They can review, discuss and vote on issues in their core areas quickly and efficiently… The jack of all trades approach isnt working Delegates (and MKR voters) with deep subject expertise would significantly improve the oversight and voting functions.  They can engage with the CUs and Community in serious discussions on key issues…

I think that @wouter is being too subtle in his response.     adcv:  and would entangle the audit function hopelessly   Hopelessly. Let’s try to refrain from making accusations? I’ll assume good faith from you and not bad intentions. Or at least tell me how SES is entangled with the @dux-core-unit *? You could not approve DUX payments, so you control them! Well, this could be true for around 3 to 4 days. After that, they would explain the situation to Governance, the funds would be returned from the Auditors wallet, and the system would be broken (and this would not look great on us). 1- This method looks horrible until you have a Core Unit removing all the funds from the wallet because they’re being offboarded (can provide a concrete example if needed). 2- You’re welcome to take over. Actually, it probably falls into your mandate more than ours. We have offered this to @aes in the past, but any Core Unit that feels like doing it, feel free to reach out. I’m not just saying this. It would be great if you could take over. (*) Sorry, DUX for using you as an example. I could have probably used @techops-core-unit or @immunefi-core-unit as well.

I’m not aware of any accusations in my post. I’m not referring to any current core units or any particular issue with SES. What I wrote was that a hypothetical audit CU that is:     adcv:  Incubating within SES or an existing Core Unit   would be entangled hopelessly, whether with SES or any others (SF for eg).

adcv:  would be entangled hopelessly, whether with SES or any others (SF for eg).   How do you think the Incubation Program works? Why would you think that talent that goes through the SES Incubation Program (or a hypothetical Strategic Finance one) would be entangled?

Again, I was only referring to a hypothetical independent audit Core Unit. As I mentioned above, I believe they would be best served to fulfill their mandate by applying through the MIP39 process to preserve to the maximum any pretensions of objectivity and neutrality. Anything short of an independent audit CU must be a mishmash of next-best alternatives such as multiple audit functions crossing over one another. It doesn’t necessarily mean it can’t work but it will just be more onerous to execute. At a smaller size it serves the purpose the best. At our size we’re on the threshold where a separate function might be more efficient in cost and valuable in performance.

adcv:  applying through the MIP39 process to preserve to the maximum any pretensions of objectivity and neutrality   Any Core Unit that graduates from the Incubation Program should have the same objectivity and neutrality than an external one. We explicitly designed the Program with that in mind. We even had Core Units not aligning with our values and vision by the end of the Program, and we think that is a feature. The delegate has to have full control over the mission, vision, and strategy. PS, delegates are aware of that, and they use that information to judge Core Units the same way as they would with a team going through the MIP39 process.

The benefits to tying subject matter expertise to delegates seems minor. Either the other delegates trust the expert and vote with him, or the expert gets ignored by other delegates and he is overruled. In either case, it doesn’t really matter that the expert is a delegate. Besides, delegates already ignore subject matter experts on votes. I don’t see why that would change.

CodeKnight:  Either the other delegates trust the expert and vote with him, or the expert gets ignored by other delegates and he is overruled. In either case, it doesn’t really matter that the expert is a delegate.   I think this underestimates the need to evaluate the relative importance of different experts. On a strategic level it is common that it’s impossible to follow the advice of every expert. At that point you have to make an informed decision between the advice of different experts or to forge a meaningful compromise between different opinions. A delegate who is an expert in a certain field will have a better understanding of that particular field and may overrule a CU expert, but will still need to consider expert opinion in fields in which he or she is not an expert.

I am talking about what the non-expert delegates will do. Being an expert on a topic doesn’t give your vote any extra weight, so votes will naturally be decided by those without special expertise on the topic. The non-expert delegates either listen to expert opinion or reject it. It won’t matter if the expert is a delegate, a CU, or a trusted community member.

Fair point.  In our current governance system subject matter expertise isnt highly valued. For Maker to flourish, i believe we need to design a governance system that encourages decisions/votes by the best qualified. I am not sure how to design governance to evolve this way

Well that is the goal of the metaDAO proposal. The metaDAOs would handle specialized projects and should be run by people who are experts in those subjects. For now, CUs kind of handle this role. They offer guidance and, if a bad proposal is passed anyway, will generally let it die on the vine. Which I agree is not an ideal system.
In theory yes the metadaos work. In reality i worry about the plan’s complexity And dependence on rather theoretical assumptions
Edited the headline to reflect that the general Voter Committees will now happen on wednesdays at 5pm CEST. Zoom link will come before this weeks call.
@rune could you please record the sessions by default?
This session will be recorded just like last one. I have already spoken to GovComms about it. And all future DVCs will be as well, since total transparency is a key objective
Today’s link: Launch Meeting - Zoom
Recording
Thank you very much @Davidutro All the content about the plan is very useful for the community.
This topic was automatically closed 91 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
